Description: The dream begins: Themes of Spring, Nature, Love, and the (poetic) song of birds
Amans dreams that he rises, dresses, and goes out into the countryside
Amans finds a river he's never seen before, washes himself, then wanders in a broad prairie
Amans discovers the Garden of Deduiz, the wall with its painted portraits
Ekphrastic description of the portraits of the courtly vices painted on the exterior of the garden wall
Amans seeks entry, finds a small gate and knocks
Oiseuse opens the gate, detailed description of her
Oiseuse recounts creation of the Garden by Deduiz; Amans expresses his desire to see more of it
Amans enters the garden, birds sing enchantingly
Amans reflects on garden, listens to birds singing, approaches Deduiz
Amans gazes at Leesce, Deduiz’ mistress
Amans watches the dance and the dancers
Lyric description of Deduiz and Leesce dancing
Douz Regart, Amors’ squire, introduced, holding Amors’ two bows and 10 arrows: 5 in his right hand, 5 in his left
Douz Regart’s arrows of love, 5 positive, 5 negative. The courtly: Biautez, Simpleice, Franchise, Compaignie, Bel Samblant; the anti-courtly: Orguelz, Vilanie, Felonie, Honte, Desesperance.
Description of the seven principal courtiers in Deduiz’ Garden
Shape of the Garden, trees and fruits
Trees and natural wonders of the Garden
Streams and fountains of the Garden
Amors follows Amans to Fountain and giant pine; inscription on edge of fountain
Amans sees prismatic crystals in the bottom of the fountain, mirror metaphor
No remedy for seeing one’s reflection
The mirror of Narcisus compared to the mirror of Virgil. Typically 36 lines.
Account of the mirror’s destructive powers
The mirror begins to reflect the garden’s roses
Amans sees the Rose: sensuous description
Amors pierces Amans’ heart with his arrows
Amors shoots Amans, effect of wound
The love wounds and their effect
Amors takes Amans 'prisoner' and demands fealty
Authorial intervention: reprise of G1a on veracity of dreams where truth is concealed but will be revealed before the end
